title: Developing a European science cloud with multiple suppliers
segmentation: My name is Vinny Olin and I'm the CEO of Cloud Sigma.
A public infrastructure as a service provider.
And we are one of the partners of the supply side of a project called Helix Nebula, which is known as the Science Cloud, which is a nifty 7 program.
Aiming to build a, let's say, demand supply side platform 4.
Cloud services for the scientific community in Europe.
So the demand side of Helix Nebula.
It consists right now of Sam E, MB, L and the European Space Agency.
And they have several problems here is.

Be number crunched and the challenge is not just a number, crunch it.

Funded by taxpayer money, so this data needs to be available for anyone to number crunch on it.
For researcher PhD student anyone?

Problem for European Space Agency which has Earth monitoring stations for example monitoring what's going on with tectonic plates and various kind of what's it called research on this.
Again, massive datasets which should be publicly available for professors, PhD students, partner universities and so on.

We actually have the desire from users to have it available.

Needed so this is a picture of IBM's Blue Jean Machine and you can imagine that this costs.
A lot more money than what a normal PhD student or professor in a normal University would be able to pay down.
So basically the problem that I've outlined now is you have massive data which needs to be available for the scientific community at large.
Underlying value is that when you make this data available, innovation will come out of it and I can give you a concrete example with the ISA.
Earth monitoring data.
So they basically have a 3D data set of planet in a very timely granular way so they can show how actually the globe is a ball that is moving.
And this has some sort of impact.
On another data set which comes from The Who which is about mosquitoes carrying malaria and then a third data set which is about humanity in the air.

OK, so the Helix Nebula.
It tries to make this as a platform we heard earlier from the Deputy Director General that the European Commission doesn't want to build something themselves.

They want all the players in the market both demand side and supply side to collaborate and build something which is commercially viable for that for the supply side, namely private companies offering various types of cloud services, not just like we do infrastructure as a service but also other types of cloud services make the we've heard from several speakers today about the pricing and in transparency in pricing.

And it's basically impossible to unless you get the end build among a month after, then you know what it costs you.

It's a group of both demand side and supply side which are now outlining.

It should be really.
Easy for an organization to go from one supplier to the next supplier.
Just like it's easy to take your car and go from one gas station to the next gas station.
And then it should just work.
So right now we are in.
This group of demand service supply side companies.
So just to give you a sense that it's several different commercial suppliers in the marketplace, all of which are more less European.

I hear today from all of you and also we see when we speak to people so basically.
You have the data privacy.
I don't think there is much new here.
Actually, in terms of the legal code, even though it's being brought up a lot.
We already have data protection.

There's another.
In Denmark, there's another in Switzerland, and so on.
This matters for EMBL you can imagine human genomes being available for researchers to number crunch on as an example.

We do it in cloud SQL just because we believe this is important.
Other providers probably will do it as well in the future.
And then the what's it called vendor login?
How easy is it to get from one supplier to another?
Again, technically it shouldn't be difficult.
It's nothing different from just downloading an actual image of a VM and putting it onto another cloud, etc.
So the final one is clarity of conditions and this is really important for the Helix Nebula project.
That terms and pricing are completely transparent because else you won't be able to really have the market forces determine the correct pricing on the demand supply equation.

Let's say Apple Air Company if you like, who then becomes the only player in town.
It should be spread out on many things.
Have the compute power as a commodity market.
We could even envision in the future that compute power starts to be traded as a financial instrument with future pricing and spot pricing on CPU.
RAM is the impact disk magnetic?

There is a reason why encryption has export bands out of the US two other countries, because actually it takes a lot of time to decrypt and then those of you who are familiar with Tier 3 and Tier 4 datacenters.
The physical protection of data.
This also already exists.
You basically in a tier three data center have five layers of protection.
Including biometric protection guards who actually carry guns and then the physical layers of just walled off data sensors and then of course.
Harmonizing the law, that would be very nice when it comes to data protection, the legal framework, but that's more of a harmonizing.
It's not creating new laws.
Actually the law is already the legal framework already exists.
So in the end, what we want is to give choice because choice it is a driver for both competitive edge and innovation.

All data.

The cloud interoperability is one of the big challenges the you mentioned that it's just moving one image from one cloud provider to the other.
This may be true for infrastructure as a service it's getting a bit more complicated if you're using a software service and you provide clean data, and then it's a bit tricky.
Yes?
So when I say the interoperability in this way from moving from cloud provider, I mean infrastructure as a service.
You get basically locked to a specific vendor and your data is stuck.
So for the IIS at least it should.
Well technically it is trivial to move, but of course some suppliers they lock you down.
There's something we don't like this something Helix Nebula doesn't like, and.

Actually, if you think about it, in a macro economic perspective, it's actually damaging everybody because the adaptation to infrastructure as a service will be slower and will not saturate as deep as if you just tell the demand site.
The companies out there look you can.
You can go to any supplier you want and you have freedom of choice.
So this is what we're trying to build.
One more.
I'm with the 128 bit security you're talking about and the obviously take forever to to crack it.
Do you think there is a security problem at all?
Yes there is.
And when you look at the statistics where the security breaches actually arise out of, it's like 80% comes out of trusted coworkers who have access.
It's not from actually all these perceived risks out there.
It's actually from people that you trust with the keys.
And it's no different from actually.
I just read some statistics.
Also, I thought.
Well, what is it like when you have?

It's totally the same.

Who has access to what?
And you can do a full audit and you do need to know basis.
What's it called systems system access to your own people?
